result.execSummary:
The defendant Steven M Jacobs was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Methamphetamine [Modifiers: Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(g).
  • Possession of Methamphetamine, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(g).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Plus supervision fees.    If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.   re Count 1 - $250 represents DNA surcharge.  re Count 4 - $250 represents DNA surcharge.
Any assessment and counseling as required and follow through and complete all required treatment.

Not to possess or consume any alcohol or controlled substance not prescribed by authorized medical personnel.  Not to possess or consume any illegal drugs.  Not to go on any premises where primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.  Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to associate with anyone using, possessing, transporting, or distributing illegal drugs or involved in illegal drug activities.
Submit a DNA sample.  Apply to Drug Court.  Forfeit all seized property.
